descript.abstract:
This data was collected by Dr. Tom Weingartner of the Institute of Marine Science, University of Alaska Fairbanks for the Gulf of Alaska LTOP (Long Term Observation Project) funded by the North Pacific Research Board, grant #708. The area of coverage is the Gulf of Alaska during September, 2007.
This data is divided into 2 parts: Header information is stored in txF07hr.dat and the CTD data is stored in txF07s.dat. Both files are contained within the WinZip archive named TXF07.zip. Both files are self-documented with descriptions of each column's data.
Data was collected on board the R/V Tiglax by a Seabird 911 Plus CTD sampling at 24 frames per second with 2 conductivity and 2 temperature sensors. Sensors are factory calibrated once per year. Accuracy of the temperature probes is better than 0.005 degrees C based on manufacturer specifications. Accuracy of the salinity values is better than 0.02 based on expected maximum drift of conductivity cell between annual factory calibrations.
CTD Pressure, Temperature and Salinity data is processed according to Seabird Inc recommended procedures. Following the automated processing, each cast is plotted and visually inspected for spikes and other signs of problems, such as spurious density inversions. Erroneous or otherwise suspect data is linearly interpolated over and flagged in the Data Quality column. The Data Quality column is assigned the following values and refer to the T & S data only: 0 = Good Data, 1 = Extrapolated, 2 = Interpolated, 3 = Poor Data Quality For Other Reason
Data units are decibars for Pressure, degrees Celcius for Termperature and Salinity is reported in terms of Practical Salinity Units (PSU), which are dimensionless. Ancillary data are reported as voltages (full range 0-5 volts) and/or as converted to engineering units described at the top of the data file and have not been subjected to any quality control measures.
descript.purpose: Project Summary: The Northern Pacific appears to have undergone a “regime shift” within the past bimodal state that is not typical of previously studied regimes. Regime shifts are often fundamental shifts in ecosystem structure and function, such as the 1976 regime shift change from a shrimp dominated fisheries to one dominated by pollock, salmon and profound impact potential, this proposal seeks to provide observations of the current Gulf of Alaska during 2007. Specifically, we seek to continue the multidisciplinary Gulf of Alaska’s Seward Line conducted by the GLOBEC program between 1997 and 2005. With the exception of the Canadian Line-P sampling program to the south, there is no other comprehensive sampling program in the Alaska Gyre that allows observation of long-term changes in of a region that is critical to Alaska’s fisheries, subsistence and tourist economies.
descript.supplinf:
This cruise was the second leg of cruise TN179 and thus was also referred to as TN179B.
The CTD data collected was assigned station numbers by the ship's data acqisition computer that did not conform to our standard numbering standards. The CTD data consecutive station numbers were therefore translated according to the following table and should be used to match with other references to this CTD data:
R/V UAF THOMPSON CONSECUTIVE STATION STATION NUMBER NUMBER ======== =========== 06101 1 06201 2 06202 3 06301 4 06401 5 06501 6 06601 7 06701 8 06801 9 06802 10 06901 11 07001 12 07101 13 07201 14 07301 15 07401 16 07501 17 07601 18 07701 19 07801 20 07802 21 07901 22 08001 23 08101 24 08201 25 08301 26 08302 27 08401 28 08402 29 08501 30 08601 31 08602 32 08701 33

attr.attrdef: water column pressure measured by the CTD
unique number within cruise associated with CTD cast
water column fluorescence measured by the CTD, reported in volts
water column dynamic height referenced to the surface
water column salinity, reported in PSU (Practical Salinity Units)
Indicates if data has been manipulated by data processing after the manufacturer-prescribed algorithms are implemented.

overview.eaover:
The following parameters are measured and reported in the CTD data file and are averaged to 1-decibar levels.
Consecutive Station Number, Pressure (decibar), Data Flag, Temperature (degrees Celcius) Salinity, Sigma-T (kg/m^3), Delta-D (Dynamic Decimeters), Fluorometer (V), PAR (V), Altimeter (V)
